Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YSR-F5T1-F0NT-H0JX-00000-00Treasurer recycles News Corp's Google attack. Will it help him? Just ask Malcolm2020-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:11ZLexisNexisTreasurer recycles News Corp's Google attack. Will it help him? Just ask MalcolmCrikeyABSTRACT

News Corp falsely claims tech giants like Google steal content from it.

FULL TEXT

Earlier this week, Treasurer Josh Frydenberg and Communications Minister Paul Fletcher got up and struck a blow for foreign multinational News Corp in its ongoing war with the tech giants that have used innovation and the internet to wreck the Murdochs' media business model. The big tech companies are deeply unpopular, usually with good reason. But the government has recycled demonstrable lies peddled by News Corp about how it is being robbed by Google and Facebook, with the aim of helping prop up News Corp's failing Australian media businesses. News Corp charges that when Google (mostly) and Facebook use its headlines and automatically generated "snippets" of News Corp stories on their sites, they are stealing content, and should be made to pay for it via a licence fee that will "reflect the financial benefit digital platforms derive from using snippets". It also complains that longer "snippets" deter people from clicking through the attached link to the original story because they get all they need from what's displayed. Except the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's (ACCC) digital platforms inquiry found that News Corp's claims don't stack up. Headlines and snippets aren't theft of content: "generally, digital platforms' use of article headlines is unlikely to infringe copyright protections in Australia," the ACCC noted. "Digital platforms reproducing a snippet of a copyright-protected news article does not infringe copyright protections if the snippet does not reproduce a substantial part of the article." And the ACCC found that the tech companies, media organisations and consumers all benefit from the use of snippets. Specifically, "media businesses benefit because a snippet provides context and an indication to the user of the value of that content, increasing the likelihood of consumers clicking through". Real-world evidence backed this up. "As a result of a German copyright law requiring Google to pay fees to publish snippets from news media websites, Google stopped showing snippets from [media company Axel Springer's] news articles. Axel Springer noted that the lack of snippets led to a nearly 40% decline in referral traffic from Google Search and an almost 80% decline in referral traffic from the Google News user interface". The ACCC also "does not agree that longer snippet lengths necessarily have a negative effect on referral traffic, with users remaining on an aggregator or search platform rather than clicking through to a news media business's website". As a result, it did not recommend that a mandatory licence fee be imposed. Where it did agree with media companies is that they have little bargaining power with Google et al when it comes to the length and composition of snippets. They can block Google from automatically generating snippets, but beyond being able to "opt out", they have no way of managing them, or maximising click-through. The ACCC thus proposed the industry-led development of a code of conduct to be agreed between media and tech companies to address this "imbalance of power" and enable media companies to get access to data and negotiate more effectively with the likes of Google. Such a code of conduct might also cover how revenue is shared "where the digital platform obtains value, directly or indirectly, from content produced by news media". How much value do digital platforms obtain from news content? Google doesn't show any ads on its news feed, and "does not generally sell advertising opportunities next to search queries that are considered by Google as having a 'news intent'". In other countries where it has been ordered to pay fees, it has simply stopped carrying snippets if it can't do so for free. In Spain, it shut down Google News. Interestingly, the result in Spain -- and one echoed elsewhere -- was that smaller media sites lost a large volume of traffic while major media sites suffered relatively little loss. It would be to News Corp's considerable advantage if that same result eventuated in Australia, with smaller competitors in an already marginal economic environment suffering a major loss in traffic. None of these facts stopped   Frydenberg and Fletcher, who have demanded the ACCC impose a mandatory code of conduct on the tech companies, backed by legislation, that would "get payment for original journalistic content". The word "content" was used repeatedly. Fletcher referred to "businesses acquiring content from another without the opportunity for a fair discussion about what they pay for it". "The ACCC", Frydenberg said, "is going to be looking at the method by which the payment for content would occur." The tech companies of course are not using any "content" beyond the headline and metadata-generated snippets that are not considered content under copyright law. And in defiance of the evidence from the ACCC, Frydenberg reiterated News Corp's claims that it "is very lucrative for the tech titans to use the original content on their website", when they do no such thing. No one, and certainly no one in the mainstream media, called out the bizarre situation of the Treasurer publicly reiterating claims by a foreign multinational that one of the country's key economic regulators -- one in his own portfolio, no less -- has publicly and at length discredited. Nor did anyone note that one possibility as a result of Frydenberg's action is that News Corp's smaller, locally owned competitors suffer a massive hit on top of what the government has created with its lockdown restrictions. Liberal politicians eager to hand wins to the foreign-owned News Corp are nothing new. Perhaps Frydenberg thinks that in aligning himself with News Corp, its editors and executives will promote him as a putative successor to Scott Morrison. In which case, Frydenberg might do well to heed the fate of Malcolm Turnbull. Turnbull as prime minister amended the media ownership laws to help News Corp, and slashed funding to its enemy the ABC. And all he got from the Murdochs was an extended effort to overthrow him.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YS9-5KS1-F0NT-H3VD-00000-00Treasurer recycles News Corp's Google attack. Will it help him? Just ask Malcolm2020-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:12ZLexisNexisTreasurer recycles News Corp's Google attack. Will it help him? Just ask MalcolmCrikeyABSTRACT

News Corp falsely claims tech giants like Google steal content from it.

FULL TEXT

Earlier this week, Treasurer Josh Frydenberg and Communications Minister Paul Fletcher got up and struck a blow for foreign multinational News Corp in its ongoing war with the tech giants that have used innovation and the internet to wreck the Murdochs' media business model. The big tech companies are deeply unpopular, usually with good reason. But the government has recycled demonstrable lies peddled by News Corp about how it is being robbed by Google and Facebook, with the aim of helping prop up News Corp's failing Australian media businesses. News Corp charges that when Google (mostly) and Facebook use its headlines and automatically generated "snippets" of News Corp stories on their sites, they are stealing content, and should be made to pay for it via a licence fee that will "reflect the financial benefit digital platforms derive from using snippets". It also complains that longer "snippets" deter people from clicking through the attached link to the original story because they get all they need from what's displayed. Except the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's (ACCC) digital platforms inquiry found that News Corp's claims don't stack up. Headlines and snippets aren't theft of content: "generally, digital platforms' use of article headlines is unlikely to infringe copyright protections in Australia," the ACCC noted. "Digital platforms reproducing a snippet of a copyright-protected news article does not infringe copyright protections if the snippet does not reproduce a substantial part of the article." And the ACCC found that the tech companies, media organisations and consumers all benefit from the use of snippets. Specifically, "media businesses benefit because a snippet provides context and an indication to the user of the value of that content, increasing the likelihood of consumers clicking through". Real-world evidence backed this up. "As a result of a German copyright law requiring Google to pay fees to publish snippets from news media websites, Google stopped showing snippets from [media company Axel Springer's] news articles. Axel Springer noted that the lack of snippets led to a nearly 40% decline in referral traffic from Google Search and an almost 80% decline in referral traffic from the Google News user interface". The ACCC also "does not agree that longer snippet lengths necessarily have a negative effect on referral traffic, with users remaining on an aggregator or search platform rather than clicking through to a news media business's website". As a result, it did not recommend that a mandatory licence fee be imposed. Where it did agree with media companies is that they have little bargaining power with Google et al when it comes to the length and composition of snippets. They can block Google from automatically generating snippets, but beyond being able to "opt out", they have no way of managing them, or maximising click-through. The ACCC thus proposed the industry-led development of a code of conduct to be agreed between media and tech companies to address this "imbalance of power" and enable media companies to get access to data and negotiate more effectively with the likes of Google. Such a code of conduct might also cover how revenue is shared "where the digital platform obtains value, directly or indirectly, from content produced by news media". How much value do digital platforms obtain from news content? Google doesn't show any ads on its news feed, and "does not generally sell advertising opportunities next to search queries that are considered by Google as having a 'news intent'". In other countries where it has been ordered to pay fees, it has simply stopped carrying snippets if it can't do so for free. In Spain, it shut down Google News. Interestingly, the result in Spain -- and one echoed elsewhere -- was that smaller media sites lost a large volume of traffic while major media sites suffered relatively little loss. It would be to News Corp's considerable advantage if that same result eventuated in Australia, with smaller competitors in an already marginal economic environment suffering a major loss in traffic. None of these facts stopped   Frydenberg and Fletcher, who have demanded the ACCC impose a mandatory code of conduct on the tech companies, backed by legislation, that would "get payment for original journalistic content". The word "content" was used repeatedly. Fletcher referred to "businesses acquiring content from another without the opportunity for a fair discussion about what they pay for it". "The ACCC", Frydenberg said, "is going to be looking at the method by which the payment for content would occur." The tech companies of course are not using any "content" beyond the headline and metadata-generated snippets that are not considered content under copyright law. And in defiance of the evidence from the ACCC, Frydenberg reiterated News Corp's claims that it "is very lucrative for the tech titans to use the original content on their website", when they do no such thing. No one, and certainly no one in the mainstream media, called out the bizarre situation of the Treasurer publicly reiterating claims by a foreign multinational that one of the country's key economic regulators -- one in his own portfolio, no less -- has publicly and at length discredited. Nor did anyone note that one possibility as a result of Frydenberg's action is that News Corp's smaller, locally owned competitors suffer a massive hit on top of what the government has created with its lockdown restrictions. Liberal politicians eager to hand wins to the foreign-owned News Corp are nothing new. Perhaps Frydenberg thinks that in aligning himself with News Corp, its editors and executives will promote him as a putative successor to Scott Morrison. In which case, Frydenberg might do well to heed the fate of Malcolm Turnbull. Turnbull as prime minister amended the media ownership laws to help News Corp, and slashed funding to its enemy the ABC. And all he got from the Murdochs was an extended effort to overthrow him.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YRF-M5P1-JD6R-T2HJ-00000-00Treasurer recycles News Corp's Google attack. Will it help him? Just ask Malcolm2020-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:11ZLexisNexisTreasurer recycles News Corp's Google attack. Will it help him? Just ask MalcolmCrikeyABSTRACT

News Corp falsely claims tech giants like Google steal content from it.

FULL TEXT

Earlier this week, Treasurer Josh Frydenberg and Communications Minister Paul Fletcher got up and struck a blow for foreign multinational News Corp in its ongoing war with the tech giants that have used innovation and the internet to wreck the Murdochs' media business model. The big tech companies are deeply unpopular, usually with good reason. But the government has recycled demonstrable lies peddled by News Corp about how it is being robbed by Google and Facebook, with the aim of helping prop up News Corp's failing Australian media businesses. News Corp charges that when Google (mostly) and Facebook use its headlines and automatically generated "snippets" of News Corp stories on their sites, they are stealing content, and should be made to pay for it via a licence fee that will "reflect the financial benefit digital platforms derive from using snippets". It also complains that longer "snippets" deter people from clicking through the attached link to the original story because they get all they need from what's displayed. Except the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's (ACCC) digital platforms inquiry found that News Corp's claims don't stack up. Headlines and snippets aren't theft of content: "generally, digital platforms' use of article headlines is unlikely to infringe copyright protections in Australia," the ACCC noted. "Digital platforms reproducing a snippet of a copyright-protected news article does not infringe copyright protections if the snippet does not reproduce a substantial part of the article." And the ACCC found that the tech companies, media organisations and consumers all benefit from the use of snippets. Specifically, "media businesses benefit because a snippet provides context and an indication to the user of the value of that content, increasing the likelihood of consumers clicking through". Real-world evidence backed this up. "As a result of a German copyright law requiring Google to pay fees to publish snippets from news media websites, Google stopped showing snippets from [media company Axel Springer's] news articles. Axel Springer noted that the lack of snippets led to a nearly 40% decline in referral traffic from Google Search and an almost 80% decline in referral traffic from the Google News user interface". The ACCC also "does not agree that longer snippet lengths necessarily have a negative effect on referral traffic, with users remaining on an aggregator or search platform rather than clicking through to a news media business's website". As a result, it did not recommend that a mandatory licence fee be imposed. Where it did agree with media companies is that they have little bargaining power with Google et al when it comes to the length and composition of snippets. They can block Google from automatically generating snippets, but beyond being able to "opt out", they have no way of managing them, or maximising click-through. The ACCC thus proposed the industry-led development of a code of conduct to be agreed between media and tech companies to address this "imbalance of power" and enable media companies to get access to data and negotiate more effectively with the likes of Google. Such a code of conduct might also cover how revenue is shared "where the digital platform obtains value, directly or indirectly, from content produced by news media". How much value do digital platforms obtain from news content? Google doesn't show any ads on its news feed, and "does not generally sell advertising opportunities next to search queries that are considered by Google as having a 'news intent'". In other countries where it has been ordered to pay fees, it has simply stopped carrying snippets if it can't do so for free. In Spain, it shut down Google News. Interestingly, the result in Spain -- and one echoed elsewhere -- was that smaller media sites lost a large volume of traffic while major media sites suffered relatively little loss. It would be to News Corp's considerable advantage if that same result eventuated in Australia, with smaller competitors in an already marginal economic environment suffering a major loss in traffic. None of these facts stopped   Frydenberg and Fletcher, who have demanded the ACCC impose a mandatory code of conduct on the tech companies, backed by legislation, that would "get payment for original journalistic content". The word "content" was used repeatedly. Fletcher referred to "businesses acquiring content from another without the opportunity for a fair discussion about what they pay for it". "The ACCC", Frydenberg said, "is going to be looking at the method by which the payment for content would occur." The tech companies of course are not using any "content" beyond the headline and metadata-generated snippets that are not considered content under copyright law. And in defiance of the evidence from the ACCC, Frydenberg reiterated News Corp's claims that it "is very lucrative for the tech titans to use the original content on their website", when they do no such thing. No one, and certainly no one in the mainstream media, called out the bizarre situation of the Treasurer publicly reiterating claims by a foreign multinational that one of the country's key economic regulators -- one in his own portfolio, no less -- has publicly and at length discredited. Nor did anyone note that one possibility as a result of Frydenberg's action is that News Corp's smaller, locally owned competitors suffer a massive hit on top of what the government has created with its lockdown restrictions. Liberal politicians eager to hand wins to the foreign-owned News Corp are nothing new. Perhaps Frydenberg thinks that in aligning himself with News Corp, its editors and executives will promote him as a putative successor to Scott Morrison. In which case, Frydenberg might do well to heed the fate of Malcolm Turnbull. Turnbull as prime minister amended the media ownership laws to help News Corp, and slashed funding to its enemy the ABC. And all he got from the Murdochs was an extended effort to overthrow him.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60RB-B3Y1-JD34-V15T-00000-00Treasurer rejects Facebook threat2020-09-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:11ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Treasurer rejects Facebook threatZoe Samios and David Crowe

Social media giants will face new laws within months to force them to pay for online content after the Morrison government stared down a sudden threat from Facebook to switch off Australian news.

Treasurer Josh Frydenberg hit back at Facebook for suggesting the news boycott, while cabinet colleagues dismissed the threat and vowed to proceed with the mandatory code by the end of the year.

In a warning to all customers yesterday, Facebook said it would stop allowing Australians to share local and international news on its main app and Instagram if the code went ahead, sparking a swift government rebuke.

"Australia makes laws that advance our national interest and we won't be responding to coercion or heavy-handed tactics, wherever they come from," Mr Frydenberg said. "We want a sustainable media environment and key to that is to seek payment for original journalistic content.

"And so we're committed to these reforms - we won't be bullied, no matter how big the international company is, no matter how powerful they are, no matter how valuable they are."

Communications Minister Paul Fletcher also pushed back at Facebook's warning, likening it to other "heavy-handed threats" that big tech companies had made in the past without putting into action.

The government response makes it clear the mandatory code on local news content will proceed as planned once the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission takes into account industry submissions made in recent days, with legislation due to go to Parliament by December.

Facebook Australia managing director Will Easton told local users yesterday that it was prepared to block news from being shared on its main app and Instagram in Australia to avoid being penalised by a world-first piece of legislation being created to make the tech giant pay for the use of news content.

"Assuming this draft code becomes law, we will reluctantly stop allowing publishers and people in Australia from sharing local and international news on Facebook and Instagram. This is not our first choice - it is our last," Mr Easton said.

The move would mean users and publishers could not publish or distribute any news articles on Facebook or Instagram.

ACCC chairman Rod Sims said the threat by Facebook was poorly timed: "Facebook's threat today to prevent any sharing of news on its services in Australia is ill-timed and misconceived."

The code, announced by the ACCC in July, will try to make global tech giants pay news media for content through an arbitrative model which includes other provisions such as notice of algorithm changes. Regulators in other markets such as France and Germany have been trying to introduce legislation to make the tech giants pay for content, but have not had success so far.

One industry observer said Google and Facebook appeared to be "playing to the international gallery" with their warnings, out of concern the Australian code might set an example for other countries.

Facebook's retaliation is similar to competitive rival Google, which launched a public attack on the code and the competition regulator two weeks ago and asked users to complain to the government about the proposal.

Historically, both platforms have been reluctant to pay for news (Facebook has made changes to its algorithm in the past that have impacted where news sits in its feed). While both have since said they are willing to remunerate publishers, there is still disagreement between publishers and the tech giants over how much the content is worth.

Facebook is particularly concerned that the model proposed by the ACCC could allow publishers to claim endless amounts of money from them. Google is more concerned about a requirement to disclose algorithm changes and with the sharing of user data.

Nine Entertainment Co (owner of this masthead) said the response was "strange" and failed to recognise the importance of balancing reliable news content with fake news made available on the platform.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WNB-3TY1-DY19-C090-00000-00Treasurer vows to curb big tech power2019-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:12ZLexisNexisTreasurer vows to curb big tech powerPaul Smith

A new division within the competition regulator will police the way in which Google and Facebook position news and advertising, as part of a wide-ranging review by the ACCC.

The federal government has warned Google and Facebook will be held to account for their actions and their algorithms will come under scrutiny to ensure they don't breach local competition laws in the positioning of content on their websites.

Treasurer Josh Frydenberg announced the measures in a long-awaited report into the market power of global platforms like Google and Facebook, which includes 23 recommendations to rein in the dominance of the US giants.

Launching his response to the report, Mr Frydenberg said the ACCC report was "truly a world first," and the government would provide its final response by the end of the year.

"Make no mistake, these companies are among the most powerful and valuable in the world. They need to be held to account and their activities need to be more transparent," Mr Frydenberg said.

The recommendations include a new unfair practices provision for Australian Consumer Law along similar lines to those in the US, UK and the EU and the creation of a new digital markets branch within the ACCC, which will act as an ombudsman for disputes related to Google and Facebook.

This branch will tackle the controversial issue of policing the algorithms used by Google and Facebook to position news and advertising. They have been accused of using this to advantage their own commercial interests.

"One of the purposes behind this new ACCC branch is to actually better understand the use of these algorithms to ensure that they're not being used for misleading or deceptive or anti-competitive conduct," Mr Frydenberg said.

"This particular branch of the ACCC will be able to be approached by various companies who believe that the algorithms have been misused in that particular way and it is the ACCC itself which will focus on those algorithms and ensure they are used in a way that is compliant with the law."

The recommendations include changes to merger laws to prevent big tech companies hoovering up potential rivals; the removal of Google as the default search option on Android devices; an inquiry into the activities of advertising technology agencies and a new platform-neutral regulatory framework to ensure consistent regulatory oversight of all entities involved in content production or delivery in Australia.

That would open up the highly controversial possibility of Facebook, Google and Twitter being held legally responsible for the content published on their platforms.

Another related recommendation is the creation of a digital platforms code to counter disinformation or "fake news", to be governed by a regulator like ACMA. This would be able to impose "sufficiently large sanctions" to act as an effective deterrent against code breaches, the ACCC report said.

World-first report

The inquiry has been closely watched around the world, as it was the first to seek to tackle the negative impacts on other businesses, and broader society of the rampant growth of online platforms.

Its draft report in December had recommended a new regulatory body be set up to make sure Google and Facebook don't abuse their market power in digital advertising, as well as a regulator to have oversight of the algorithms used to position news stories and advertising content.

It also proposed a digital platforms ombudsman with the power to rule on disputes between local companies and global platforms, which are currently fought entirely on "take it or leave it" terms, and are very much weighted in the platforms' favour, and one to rule on disputes with local individuals and organisations.

Since the ACCC first announced its inquiry, and also released its draft findings last December, the US Federal Trade Commission has begun investigating both Facebook and Google on antitrust grounds, and whacked Facebook with a $US5 billion fine for misleading its users about privacy breaches.

Submissions to the inquiry expressed a wish for strong measures, such as a News Corp call for a functional separation of Google's search and advertising businesses, in order to prevent it favouring content that benefited its own commercial interests.

The government has been increasingly outspoken in its wish to come down hard on the regulation of big global tech platforms operating in Australia in recent times.

Following the Christchurch Mosque shootings, which were live-streamed and widely shared on Facebook and other online platforms, Prime Minister Scott Morrison dragged representatives of the companies to a crisis meeting in Brisbane, where executives were threatened with possible jail terms if they didn't smarten their acts up.

He also used the global spotlight of the G20 in June to organise and international edict that insisted that social media companies do more to police their conduct, under the threat of legislation.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X1K-SJJ1-DY1R-B1KN-00000-00Treasury admits this: users will pay for VAT to technology companies; if not paid, the SAT will veto companies in Mexico2019-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:11ZLexisNexisTreasury admits this: users will pay for VAT to technology companies; if not paid, the SAT will veto companies in MexicoOscar Steve


There are already three different proposals to tax, with new taxes or not, on digital platforms by 2020 in Mexico. One is discussed in the Chamber of Deputies, one in the Senate, and another comes from the Federal Government, with a new procedure to make techpay VAT, even if they are outside the country.



All agree:technology companies must be taxed. But the Treasury makes a pronouncement that is much sought to avoid saying, and that is that VAT will end up moving to end user,because, inevitably, it is your responsibility to take over the Value Added Tax. The initiative reads verbatim:

"It should be noted that the tax burden on VAT on the digital services they intend to tax will fall on the final consumer, who from an economic point of view is the tax payer. Where the services mentioned are purchased by undertakings, the economic effect is neutral, since the VAT transferred by the digital service provider is atissueable against the VAT caused by the company in the same month in which this happens"

The determination, however stark it may seem, does not really correspond to Hacienda, namely Gonzalo Rojo, associate director of The Competitive Intelligence Unit. The Treasury does not really have any interference as to whether or not technology platforms decide to absorb the extra VAT expenditure they must pay, or, although, they decide to transfer it to their users.

But yes, in some cases it will be inevitable that VAT will end up being moved to the end user.

That is not to say, according to the telecommunications specialist Javier Tejado and the director of The CIU, Ernesto Piedras, that technology companies should not pay taxes. In the end, regulations for taxing the digital economy are advancing at a slow but steady pace outside Mexico. Both in an interview with W Radio have agreed that the digital economy must be taxed, but the subject of the G20, G7, and to be discussed for the 2020 revenue in Mexico, is in the how.

All digital economy contributors in the same basket

The big problem with the Treasury's proposal is that all technology platforms are being considered equal. Thus, Treasury will tax in the same way a Finnish developer with mail management service that offers a monthly subscription, as to Google. In France, in fact, a very clear distinction has been made, where the four great tech companies, known by their acronyms as GAFA (Google, Amazon, Facebook, Apple), already have a 3% tax on their income in the country.

The Treasury doesn't make that distinction. Rojo explains that the Treasury proposal includes any foreign company, regardless of the size of revenue they generate in Mexico. There, the proposal is different from that put forward by the deputy of Morena, Ramírez Cuellar, earlier this year, and the proposal by the senator of Morena, Ricardo Monreal, which establishes a profit floor of 800 million pesos: if a company generates more than this in Méxic or, then you should pay the corresponding VAT.

Rojo is concerned about the vastness of categories included in the Treasury proposal, which includes everything from online dating services, cloud storage, streaming services, and even education. "I was very struck by the inclusion of educational services," says Rojo, which would involve platforms like Coursera and Khan Academy. The proposal reads in textual form:

"The proposal under consideration does not apply to all digital services but exclusively to a category of services that are generally final consumer in households or used by individuals for theirindividual consumption, such as downloading or accessing images, movies, text, information, video, audio, music, games, including gambling, as well as other multimedia content, multiplayer environments, obtaining mobile ringtones, viewing online news, traffic information, weather forecasts and statistics. Examples of the above are audio or video streaming services to watch movies or listen to music, among others. Also in this category are digital services of online clubs and dating pages, data storage, as well as distance learning services or tests or exercises".

Rojo explains that the leap that is taking place in Mexico is huge. While other countries are discussing which platforms to tax, there has been a consensus that streaming platforms should top the list, but from there, the debate continues. "Ithink we did something very upto us, very quickly (...) you can't put everything in the same basket, especially talking about education."

Streaming platforms lead the first places on technology platforms to record because they arrive directly at end-user, have entertainment purposes, and mainly reach medium and high socio-economic levels

In this sense Senator Monreal's proposal is much more measured. It only mentions streaming platforms, although it does indicate that the rest should be taxed, only in time.

In fact, the initiative expresses support for Europe's GAFA tax, and in a transitional article states that no later than 360 days after its approval, Mexico must impose a new excise duty of 3% on the profits of the rest of the companies always in the light of what happens in the next year of global platform tax debate and the comments it makes to the OECD about it.

No waiting for the Treasury. If all technology companies are approved, they should be responding for their VAT and ISR by 1 April 2020.

The SAT, the new executioner of the connection to the network of companies in Mexico

Of the most interesting items of the Treasury's proposal is that for companies residing abroad to pay their taxes, they must have a legal representative residing in Mexico. To say of Rojo, large companies would not have the least of the problems, considering that most of them already have offices in the country. The problem would be more in medium and small businesses, with digital services the size of small iOS and Android apps.

In fact, many of the big tech companies in Mexico are already issuing an invoice. For Javier Tejado, the matter of the Treasury proposal is rather important because it sets the collection procedure, which to this day shines because of its non-existence in Mexico's tax laws.

The most interesting part is when we get to the sanctions. The Treasury initiative states that, if a global technology company that is not resident in Mexico refuses to register with the SAT, then the SAT will have the power to go to broadband service dealers(read Telmex, Izzi, AT&T; or other ),and ask you to unsubscribe the connection that companies make to provide their service in the country.

"There I think it's also not very functional," says Rojo, adding convinced,"it's virtually impossible." Not only is it the issue of the technological and human resource arm that would be needed to find every digital service provider globally that providessome kind of service in Mexico, but the inability to trace their connections in the country. "The government doesn't even have time to do that kind of thing, and we'd become China because we were blocking services," says Rojo.

But if for some reason the procedure could be carried out, and dealers took more than five days to make the connection cut, then would be creditors to fines ranging from 500,000 pesos per million pesos.

"Given the possibility of non-compliance that could occur, it is necessary to impose a penalty for such non-compliance, for which it is proposed to establish in the CFF an article 90 Bis to establish a fine of $500,000.00 to $1'000,000.00 for the non-compliance, a penalty that will also apply for each calendar month that occurs without complying with the suspension order"

The other two proposals are rather less elaborate. Ramírez Cuellar's establishes a VAT withholding procedure facilitated through banks and other financial institutions, similar to that of Monreal's proposal, where banks must also take charge of the collection when payment is made debit, credit, departmental or prepaid card.

If digital platforms serve as intermediaries then the scheme is different. In the case of Uber, ARBNB and similar companies that serve as a link between a service or product provider and the end consumer, it would be the platforms that must be responsible for the collection of the ISR of the transactions, according to the Initiative of the Treasury. "This is justified by the fact that these platforms have control and record of transactions that are carried out between their users (as much as alaw, service providers and their customers)" reads in the initiative.

There's a minimum income floor here. If the total income of natural persons does not exceed 300 thousand pesos per year, then the ISR can be paid under the law, but if the limit is exceeded or natural persons earn income from different salaries then the withholding made by the platform would be provisional only.

The scheme is not a very different one from the one that Uber and the like have started to apply in Mexico since the end of 2018, only that until now it has remained as a project in pilot phase and with optional application by the platforms.

With so many changes happening rapidly, Rojo's main concern is that the necessary discussion about the most optimal regulation around the levy on technology companies simply hasn't happened. "I think it's a new world, it's a complex world, in which serious analysis and time is required to be able to do something serious. If we don't get lost a lot and we can leave legal holes."

In the worst-case scenario, an incorrect tax regime could discourage innovation, restrict the use of digital services (including e-commerce), and even inhibit internet access from the most disadvantaged economic sectors, without to stop mentioning, of course, encouraging unequal access to digital educational services.

Although the digital economy must be taxed, so far we may have lived in a fiscal bubble. Now to get into the matter is to burst the bubble in the least shrill way possible.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WK6-MPF1-JC65-51X1-00000-00Treasury chief: Facebook currency plan ripe for illicit use2019-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:11ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSTreasury chief: Facebook currency plan ripe for illicit useBy MARCY GORDONAP Business WriterWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - The Trump administration came out strongly Monday against Facebook's ambitious plan to create a new digital currency, as the Treasury chief warned it could be used for illicit activity such as money laundering, human trafficking and financing terrorism.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed "very serious concerns" about the currency proposed by the social network giant, to be called Libra. "This is indeed a national security issue," Mnuchin told reporters at the White House.

His comments came a few days after President Donald Trump tweeted that Libra "will have little standing or dependability."

Trump, fresh off a "social media summit" he led at the White House that gathered conservative critics of Big Tech, tweeted last week: "I am not a fan of Bitcoin and other Cryptocurrencies, which are not money, and whose value is highly volatile and based on thin air. Unregulated Crypto Assets can facilitate unlawful behavior, including drug trade and other illegal activity."

If they want to get into the financial business, Facebook and its dozens of partner companies in the venture will have to accept the kind of tight regulation that banks are under, the president said.

The Treasury chief's comments went further, though, tying Libra directly to concerns over potential use for money laundering, drug and human trafficking, tax evasion and other crimes.

The Treasury Department has "very serious concerns that Libra could be misused by money launderers and terrorist financers," he said.

Facebook has "a lot of work to do before we get to the point where we're comfortable with it," Mnuchin said.

On Tuesday, Congress begins two days of hearings on Facebook's Libra plan. The head of the Federal Reserve also raised an alarm about the plan last week.

Facebook's plan "raises a lot of serious concerns, and those would include around privacy, money laundering, consumer protection, financial stability," Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said in congressional testimony. "Those are going to need to be thoroughly and publicly assessed and evaluated before this proceeds."

Unlike Mnuchin, Powell - as head of the central bank - is an independent regulator who is separate from the administration and political influence.

Already under intense scrutiny from regulators and Congress over privacy and market dominance, Facebook stirred anger on Capitol Hill last month with the unveiling of its plan to create a new financial ecosystem based on a digital currency. Senate and House hearings went on the calendar, and the Democratic head of the House Financial Services Committee called on Facebook to suspend the plan until Congress and regulators can review it.

Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., said that Facebook, with some 2 billion users around the world, "is continuing its unchecked expansion and extending its reach into the lives of its users." She called Libra "a new Swiss-based financial system" that potentially is too big to fail and could require a taxpayer bailout.

David Marcus, the Facebook executive leading the project, says in his testimony prepared for Tuesday's hearing by the Financial Services panel that Libra "is about developing a safe, secure and low-cost way for people to move money efficiently around the world. We believe that Libra can make real progress toward building a more inclusive financial infrastructure."

Facebook agrees with Powell's view that the government's review of Libra must be "patient and thorough, rather than a sprint to implementation," Marcus' statement says. "The time between now and launch is designed to be an open process and subject to regulatory oversight and review. In fact, I expect that this will be the broadest, most extensive and most careful pre-launch oversight by regulators and central banks in FinTech's history. We know we need to take the time to get this right."

The planned digital currency is billed as a "stablecoin" backed by deposits in sovereign currencies such as the dollar, euro and Japanese yen - unlike bitcoin, ether or other digital currencies. Promising low fees, it could open online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts and make it cheaper to send money across borders. But it also raises concerns over the privacy of users' data and the potential for criminals to use it for money laundering and fraud.

To address privacy concerns, Facebook created a nonprofit oversight association, with dozens of partners including PayPal, Uber, Spotify, Visa and MasterCard to govern Libra. As one among many in the association, Facebook says it won't have any special rights or privileges. It also created a "digital wallet" subsidiary, Calibra, to work on the technology, separately from its main social media business. While Facebook owns and controls Calibra, it won't see financial data from Calibra, the company says.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WK6-MR91-JC65-52JF-00000-00Treasury chief: Facebook currency plan ripe for illicit use2019-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:11ZLexisNexisWASHINGTON DATELINETreasury chief: Facebook currency plan ripe for illicit useBy MARCY GORDONAP Business WriterWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON (AP) - The Trump administration came out strongly Monday against Facebook's ambitious plan to create a new digital currency, as the Treasury chief warned it could be used for illicit activity such as money laundering, human trafficking and financing terrorism.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed "very serious concerns" about the currency proposed by the social network giant, to be called Libra. "This is indeed a national security issue," Mnuchin told reporters at the White House.

His comments came a few days after President Donald Trump tweeted that Libra "will have little standing or dependability."

Trump, fresh off a "social media summit" he led at the White House that gathered conservative critics of Big Tech, tweeted last week: "I am not a fan of Bitcoin and other Cryptocurrencies, which are not money, and whose value is highly volatile and based on thin air. Unregulated Crypto Assets can facilitate unlawful behavior, including drug trade and other illegal activity."

If they want to get into the financial business, Facebook and its dozens of partner companies in the venture will have to accept the kind of tight regulation that banks are under, the president said.

The Treasury chief's comments went further, though, tying Libra directly to concerns over potential use for money laundering, drug and human trafficking, tax evasion and other crimes.

The Treasury Department has "very serious concerns that Libra could be misused by money launderers and terrorist financers," he said.

Facebook has "a lot of work to do before we get to the point where we're comfortable with it," Mnuchin said.

On Tuesday, Congress begins two days of hearings on Facebook's Libra plan. The head of the Federal Reserve also raised an alarm about the plan last week.

Facebook's plan "raises a lot of serious concerns, and those would include around privacy, money laundering, consumer protection, financial stability," Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said in congressional testimony. "Those are going to need to be thoroughly and publicly assessed and evaluated before this proceeds."

Unlike Mnuchin, Powell - as head of the central bank - is an independent regulator who is separate from the administration and political influence.

Already under intense scrutiny from regulators and Congress over privacy and market dominance, Facebook stirred anger on Capitol Hill last month with the unveiling of its plan to create a new financial ecosystem based on a digital currency. Senate and House hearings went on the calendar, and the Democratic head of the House Financial Services Committee called on Facebook to suspend the plan until Congress and regulators can review it.

Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., said that Facebook, with some 2 billion users around the world, "is continuing its unchecked expansion and extending its reach into the lives of its users." She called Libra "a new Swiss-based financial system" that potentially is too big to fail and could require a taxpayer bailout.

David Marcus, the Facebook executive leading the project, says in his testimony prepared for Tuesday's hearing by the Financial Services panel that Libra "is about developing a safe, secure and low-cost way for people to move money efficiently around the world. We believe that Libra can make real progress toward building a more inclusive financial infrastructure."

Facebook agrees with Powell's view that the government's review of Libra must be "patient and thorough, rather than a sprint to implementation," Marcus' statement says. "The time between now and launch is designed to be an open process and subject to regulatory oversight and review. In fact, I expect that this will be the broadest, most extensive and most careful pre-launch oversight by regulators and central banks in FinTech's history. We know we need to take the time to get this right."

The planned digital currency is billed as a "stablecoin" backed by deposits in sovereign currencies such as the dollar, euro and Japanese yen - unlike bitcoin, ether or other digital currencies. Promising low fees, it could open online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts and make it cheaper to send money across borders. But it also raises concerns over the privacy of users' data and the potential for criminals to use it for money laundering and fraud.

To address privacy concerns, Facebook created a nonprofit oversight association, with dozens of partners including PayPal, Uber, Spotify, Visa and MasterCard to govern Libra. As one among many in the association, Facebook says it won't have any special rights or privileges. It also created a "digital wallet" subsidiary, Calibra, to work on the technology, separately from its main social media business. While Facebook owns and controls Calibra, it won't see financial data from Calibra, the company says.

If they want to get into the financial business, Facebook and its dozens of partner companies in the venture will have to accept the kind of tight regulation that banks are under, the president said.

The Treasury chief 's comments went further, though, tying Libra directly to concerns over potential use for money laundering, drug and human trafficking, tax evasion and other crimes.

Facebook has "a lot of work to do before we get to the point where we're comfortable with it," Mnuchin said.

On Tuesday, Congress begins two days of hearings on Facebook's Libra plan. The head of the Federal Reserve also raised an alarm about the plan last week.

Facebook's plan "raises a lot of serious concerns, and those would include around privacy, money laundering, consumer protection, financial stability," Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said in congressional testimony. "Those are going to need to be thoroughly and publicly assessed and evaluated before this proceeds."

Unlike Mnuchin, Powell — as head of the central bank — is an independent regulator who is separate from the administration and political influence.

Already under intense scrutiny from regulators and Congress over privacy and market dominance, Facebook stirred anger on Capitol Hill last month with the unveiling of its plan to create a new financial ecosystem based on a digital currency. Senate and House hearings went on the calendar, and the Democratic head of the House Financial Services Committee called on Facebook to suspend the plan until Congress and regulators can review it.

Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., said that Facebook, with some 2 billion users around the world, "is continuing its unchecked expansion and extending its reach into the lives of its users." She called Libra "a new Swiss-based financial system" that potentially is too big to fail and could require a taxpayer bailout.

David Marcus, the Facebook executive leading the project, says in his testimony prepared for Tuesday's hearing by the Financial Services panel that Libra "is about developing a safe, secure and low-cost way for people to move money efficiently around the world. We believe that Libra can make real progress toward building a more inclusive financial infrastructure."

Facebook agrees with Powell's view that the government's review of Libra must be "patient and thorough, rather than a sprint to implementation," Marcus' statement says. "The time between now and launch is designed to be an open process and subject to regulatory oversight and review. In fact, I expect that this will be the broadest, most extensive and most careful pre-launch oversight by regulators and central banks in FinTech's history. We know we need to take the time to get this right."

The planned digital currency is billed as a "stablecoin" backed by deposits in sovereign currencies such as the dollar, euro and Japanese yen — unlike bitcoin, ether or other digital currencies. Promising low fees, it could open online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts and make it cheaper to send money across borders. But it also raises concerns over the privacy of users' data and the potential for criminals to use it for money laundering and fraud.

To address privacy concerns, Facebook created a nonprofit oversight association, with dozens of partners including PayPal, Uber, Spotify, Visa and MasterCard to govern Libra. As one among many in the association, Facebook says it won't have any special rights or privileges. It also created a "digital wallet" subsidiary, Calibra, to work on the technology, separately from its main social media business. While Facebook owns and controls Calibra, it won't see financial data from Calibra, the company says.

urn:contentItem:5WK8-1F01-JBVR-30JV-00000-00Treasury chief: Facebook currency plan ripe for illicit use;Treasury chief: Facebook currency plan ripe for illicit use2019-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:11ZLexisNexisBUSINESSTreasury chief: Facebook currency plan ripe for illicit useTreasury chief: Facebook currency plan ripe for illicit useMarcy GordonThe Associated Press

WASHINGTON - The Trump administration came out strongly Monday against Facebook's ambitious plan to create a new digital currency, as the Treasury chief warned it could be used for illicit activity such as money laundering, human trafficking and financing terrorism.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed "very serious concerns" about the currency proposed by the social network giant, to be called Libra. "This is indeed a national security issue," Mnuchin told reporters at the White House.

His comments came a few days after President Donald Trump tweeted that Libra "will have little standing or dependability."

Trump, fresh off a "social media summit" he led at the White House that gathered conservative critics of Big Tech, tweeted last week: "I am not a fan of Bitcoin and other Cryptocurrencies, which are not money, and whose value is highly volatile and based on thin air. Unregulated Crypto Assets can facilitate unlawful behaviour, including drug trade and other illegal activity."

If they want to get into the financial business, Facebook and its dozens of partner companies in the venture will have to accept the kind of tight regulation that banks are under, the president said.

The Treasury chief's comments went further, though, tying Libra directly to concerns over potential use for money laundering, drug and human trafficking, tax evasion and other crimes.

The Treasury Department has "very serious concerns that Libra could be misused by money launderers and terrorist financers," he said.

Facebook has "a lot of work to do before we get to the point where we're comfortable with it," Mnuchin said.

On Tuesday, Congress begins two days of hearings on Facebook's Libra plan. The head of the Federal Reserve also raised an alarm about the plan last week.

Facebook's plan "raises a lot of serious concerns, and those would include around privacy, money laundering, consumer protection, financial stability," Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said in congressional testimony. "Those are going to need to be thoroughly and publicly assessed and evaluated before this proceeds."

Unlike Mnuchin, Powell - as head of the central bank - is an independent regulator who is separate from the administration and political influence.

Already under intense scrutiny from regulators and Congress over privacy and market dominance, Facebook stirred anger on Capitol Hill last month with the unveiling of its plan to create a new financial ecosystem based on a digital currency. Senate and House hearings went on the calendar, and the Democratic head of the House Financial Services Committee called on Facebook to suspend the plan until Congress and regulators can review it.

Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., said that Facebook, with some 2 billion users around the world, "is continuing its unchecked expansion and extending its reach into the lives of its users." She called Libra "a new Swiss-based financial system" that potentially is too big to fail and could require a taxpayer bailout.

David Marcus, the Facebook executive leading the project, says in his testimony prepared for Tuesday's hearing by the Financial Services panel that Libra "is about developing a safe, secure and low-cost way for people to move money efficiently around the world. We believe that Libra can make real progress toward building a more inclusive financial infrastructure."

Facebook agrees with Powell's view that the government's review of Libra must be "patient and thorough, rather than a sprint to implementation," Marcus' statement says. "The time between now and launch is designed to be an open process and subject to regulatory oversight and review. In fact, I expect that this will be the broadest, most extensive and most careful pre-launch oversight by regulators and central banks in FinTech's history. We know we need to take the time to get this right."

The planned digital currency is billed as a "stablecoin" backed by deposits in sovereign currencies such as the dollar, euro and Japanese yen - unlike bitcoin, ether or other digital currencies. Promising low fees, it could open online commerce to millions of people around the world who lack access to bank accounts and make it cheaper to send money across borders. But it also raises concerns over the privacy of users' data and the potential for criminals to use it for money laundering and fraud.

To address privacy concerns, Facebook created a non-profit oversight association, with dozens of partners including PayPal, Uber, Spotify, Visa and MasterCard to govern Libra. As one among many in the association, Facebook says it won't have any special rights or privileges. It also created a "digital wallet" subsidiary, Calibra, to work on the technology, separately from its main social media business. While Facebook owns and controls Calibra, it won't see financial data from Calibra, the company says.
