value.Title: Treasury Secretary Mnuchin Delivers Remarks at DealBook DC Strategy Forum

Extracts.SummaryText: MNUCHIN: Well, first of all, let me just say again. I appreciate the work you've done in these areas. I think apprenticeships are very important. I also think, and this is an area you know we've worked with you on financial literacy is also very important. So, some of these issues and Ivanka Trump has done a great job spearheading this out of the White House with--with many companies. Job training, apprenticeship--incentivizing companies to do this and cutting back regulations so that companies ...

<xhtml:span id="h1" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... crop? Apple , Amazon --I--I know they all hate being called <xhtml:span class="hit">big tech</xhtml:span> and being lobbed into one thing, but if you think about ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h2" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... companies. Job training, apprenticeship--incentivizing companies to do this and cutting back <xhtml:span class="hit">regulations</xhtml:span> so that companies can do it effectively. Anything we can do ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h3" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... are--these are complicated issues, but you're talking about banks that are <xhtml:span class="hit">regulated</xhtml:span> and have FDIC insurance. SORKIN: Right. MNUCHIN: Which is a benefit ...</xhtml:span>

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X20-JGB1-F15W-H4F1-00000-00Treasury Secretary Mnuchin Delivers Remarks at DealBook DC Strategy Forum2019-09-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:12ZLexisNexisTreasury Secretary Mnuchin Delivers Remarks at DealBook DC Strategy Forum

Treasury Secretary Mnuchin Delivers Remarks At Dealbook Dc Strategy Forum

September 12, 2019 05:00 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY STEVEN MNUCHIN

NEW YORK TIMES FINANCIAL COLUMNIST ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

[*]MNUCHIN: Thank you. It's actually--

SORKIN: Good afternoon.

MNUCHIN: Thank you. It's actually quite fascinating getting the end of the tax briefing.

SORKIN: You're getting--you're getting the extended--Well, we have a lot--a lot of people. We have Grover's (SP) here. You can Mark Zandi is over there.

MNUCHIN: Absolutely.

SORKIN: We've got Glenn Hubbard. We've got a whole-where's Steve Rattner? I don't know. We have a whole group here, and there's some really remarkable people here, this afternoon.

I have a series of questions, and then I do want to open up because I know there are people here who do so we're going to pretend that it's like TV.

MNUCHIN: Wait, I thought I was going to get to ask you questions.

SORKIN: Oh, you can do--you want to? What do you want to do?

MNUCHIN: So, are you more famous for CNBC or Billions?

(LAUGHTER)

SORKIN: From the New York Times?

MNUCHIN: Or the New York Times.

SORKIN: How about that? We'll go with the times.

(APPLAUSE)

We'll go with the times.

(LAUGHTER)

(APPLAUSE)

Here's where I want to start the conversation. You were on TV this morning, as it happens--

MNUCHIN: I was?

SORKIN: Talking about China and you seem to sound a note of optimism about the state of these negotiations. It seemed like. I don't know if you think that's an accurate way to put it. But I wanted to read you because I was reading Tom Friedman in the New York Times, no less, just yesterday and he just got back from China. And he said that he left feeling that--that though--that President Xi is less likely to sign on to the kind of grand bargain and broad concessions that the president is demanding. And that's in part because Xi would get too much pushback from his state-owned industries and Communist Party hardliners. And I wanted to understand the juxtaposition of what Tom was saying and what I think you've been thinking unless you're in agreement.

MNUCHIN: Let me--let me first put this in context because these issues have been going on for the last 20 years through both parties. So, this is not necessarily a party for a philosophical issue. President Trump came into office and at the first meeting that he had with President Xi, this was on the agenda, and President Trump said that when need to rebalance the trading relationship that this is a one-way street. That you're able to invest in the U.S. freely, you're able to export freely. We want fair and reciprocal trade and President Xi agreed to that.

And I think as you know, for the last 2.5 years, we've been at different stages of executing this. I wouldn't make the comment whether I'm optimistic or pessimistic, I'd make the comment that the next month is important. I take them at good faith. We're going to have a deputy's level meeting. I believe it's next week to do preliminary work. Followed by the beginning of October a meeting with the Vice Premier and Ambassador Lighthizer and myself and we're hopeful we'll make progress if we can get the right deal. We'll do a deal.

SORKIN: Within the administration, the departure of Mr. Bolton. Does that change any of the dynamics--

MNUCHIN: Not at all.

SORKIN: For you?

MNUCHIN: No.

SORKIN: At all? Does it make it easier?

MNUCHIN: Not--not--not--not at all. Nothing against Ambassador Bolton, but these are the president's strategies. This is executing on the president, and I--I think that we're much more unified on these issues than the external world, would in any way, like to report it.

SORKIN: Okay. Here's a different question. Brad Smith was here earlier from Microsoft, and we were talking about Huawei and its role in these negotiations. Is there a way to you--it feels that Huawei has become a bit over a--a pawn, if you will, in these negotiations? Is the--could you see the president trading something on Huawei for the trade deal?

MNUCHIN: No, and--and I--I don't think it's fair to say that it's a pawn and I think you know one of the things about the--the treasury role is I spin a lot of different issues in the administration, so I sit on--on the National Security Council, and I'm obviously focused on economic issues as well, so I--I get to see both sides of this. Part of the Huawei issue is clearly a national security issue. There's no question about that, and we've had discussions with our allies on it.

There are other parts of the Huawei issue that are not, and what President Trump said to President Xi last time was we will consider licenses for things that are not of national security concern.

SORKIN: But is there--I--I think the question is when Huawei gets painted as a national security threat, how that gets--how it's possible to make a deal over that, and there are people who you know--by the way, Democrats and Republicans who think Huawei needs to effectively just be shut down completely.

MNUCHIN: Well again, I think when you say there are people who think it should be shut down. I think there are people on one side of the spectrum who would like them not to do business in the United States. I think that that's not saying they should be necessarily shut down in China.

SORKIN: Okay. Let me ask you a separate question, and this is something that--that--that Brad Smith and I were also talking about, just--just earlier. What do you think the difference is between the relationship between Huawei and the Chinese government and the relationship between the U.S. government and U.S. business? And the reason--

MNUCHIN: Very different.

SORKIN: But the reason I asked the question is because I--I think there's a view that the Chinese can ask Huawei to go use their systems to bug other people and do other things. But I also think there is a view, and we heard it actually to some degree from Brad, though I think he thinks there's more protections for him to say no. But clearly, the U.S. government is often asking U.S. businesses to help.

MNUCHIN: Well, you're--you're commenting on things that I obviously am--am not about to comment on because obviously I'm pretty to information and I can't comment on these things. I would just say categorically I think there is a giant difference between the two things that you're describing.

SORKIN: In terms--in terms of those relationships?

MNUCHIN: Absolutely.

SORKIN: Because one--can be a forced issue and the other--

MNUCHIN: I mean--again, I don't want to go through all--

SORKIN: Right.

MNUCHIN: All the details but I don't think it's fair to say in any way that the relationship in the United States between the government and private businesses--

SORKIN: Right.

MNUCHIN: Is the same as the relationship between China and state-owned--state enterprise businesses. Now, where Huawei fits in, again, you know I'm not going to, specifically on that but you're talking about different relationships.

SORKIN: Related question, and I also asked Brad this, what do you think it means to be a patriotic company in America today? And the reason we're talking about this is there are so many American companies, especially in the Valley today who have historically done business with--with the U.S. government but have recently become--reticent and I don't know if that's a political. I don't know if you have a view that that's--that that's because they disagree with the administration. I don't know if you think it's a--an ethical or moral view but put that all sort of any frame in terms of how you think about it in terms of how business relates to the government right now.

MNUCHIN: Well, I--I think in the United States we support private enterprise and private rights, and there's a whole different level of spectrum in regard to how--how companies act. Obviously, companies have different constituencies, whether it's boards, or shareholders, or customers, and there's all different ways that companies can act with the government. And I would also say it depends on what industry you're in. There are certain industries where the businesses get a lot of benefits from the government, so clearly I don't think it should be a one-way street, but I think what you're touching on is--is a complicated issue, but I'd say, look, we do have--we believe in enterprise, and we believe in a capitalistic society.

SORKIN: Well let--let me--let me ask you then about that because the other related issue to this is that when you think a little bit about the way the government assigns contracts or doesn't to you-- the U.S. enter--U.S. enterprise there has been, and I'm going to give--give you an example of this, right now, there's a question about whether Amazon and AWS is going to continue to have this $10 billion Pentagon contract. And there's a view that politics are involved in that and that's why I'm trying--I'm sort of get it that--sort of central core of how you think those things come together.

MNUCHIN: Well, let me just say some of these issues are very complicated issues.

SORKIN: Right.

MNUCHIN: And I don't think in any way there as simple as political issues. Again, I can't comment on the specifics of the DOD contract. I can tell you that I--I am aware of and I been briefed on the issues of transferring to the cloud.

SORKIN: Right.

MNUCHIN: It is something that I've--I've spoken to many of the agencies, and we've looked at and I--I think the idea of using the cloud and using external vendors is something that's very important for the government. On the other hand, I think from the government standpoint, we do need to balance these risks, specifically in industries where there are very few providers of the services and what dependence the government ultimately has sense when we move these things these are our long-term relationships. Some of them have to do with issues of encryption and comply--complex issues, but I--I--I can assure you this is way beyond a--a--a political issue.

SORKIN: Okay.

MNUCHIN: I think another complex issue on--on Amazon is you have one of the largest cloud providers attached to a giant retailer so, I mean one of the questions is, who knows what Amazon looks like 10 years down the road? Or are these--are they still attached or are they not attached?

SORKIN: Okay. Let me ask you that. We've had a conversation today about antitrust America, and right now, there's obviously a lot of attention on those big companies. When you look back--actually maybe the question is to look even at Microsoft. Do you think that it was an advantage, that it was the right thing for the U.S. government to ultimately go after Microsoft? Did that make the--the--the Silicon Valley more competitive?

MNUCHIN: I mean, to be honest with you, there's a lot of things I consider myself an expert on, that's not one of them, and I don't know enough of the facts to look back and--

SORKIN: Right.

MNUCHIN: And have a view on that.

SORKIN: How do you look at then this crop? Apple, Amazon--I--I know they all hate being called big tech and being lobbed into one thing, but if you think about Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google together, right now. What are your--

MNUCHIN: Again, I--I think it's easy to group all these technology companies because they are all big technology companies. I think they're all very different. I mean if you take Apple as an example. Apple is in a very competitive business with Samsung.

SORKIN: Right.

MNUCHIN: They're also in a competitive business with Huawei. So again, I think it's unfair to say , look, we should just look at the antitrust issues that all these companies have the same issues. They have very different issues. I have said, and again, this isn't in my domain, but I--I do think the Justice Department will look at some of these issues as it relates to some of these companies.

SORKIN: Okay, this is a hard one for you. Your boss--just because you mentioned Amazon. You are--your boss goes on Twitter and--and--and calls the leader of Amazon, Jeff Bezos. What do you think of that when you see that? I'm just curious.

MNUCHIN: The president going back to the campaign come up with some very creative names for people. So, I think people understand how he uses these names.

SORKIN: And--but in practice as part of this larger negotiation that's just going on every single day. Are you--do you--do you call him and say I really wish you hadn't said that?

MNUCHIN: There's lots of things on--on policies and everything else that I talked to the president about. I really don't get into these issues.

SORKIN: You--you--the name-calling.

MNUCHIN: I would call it name-calling. I would--again, but--

SORKIN: Okay, I have a different one for but related. I don't know if you saw this earlier this week. Elliott Management, the activist firm decided they were going to go after AT&T and the president put out a--a tweet saying great news an activist investor is now involved with AT&T. Now, of course, he's very upset with CNN but as the Treasurer Secretary, as somebody who deals with business every day. How do you think about that?

MNUCHIN: I think it's always great if company's--if investors get more involved with companies. I think quite frankly one of the biggest problems we have is that boards are not active enough, that large shareholders are not active enough. We have obviously a huge amount of assets that are going into index funds. So, I think shareholders should be well represented.

SORKIN: Okay, so that's actually very interesting because there's a--there is a view, especially when it comes to this idea that people need to be long-term thinking, that actually activist shareholders have not been--have not helped that--that cause.

MNUCHIN: I--I think quite the opposite. I--I think many times I mean you know look, Warren Buffett. I mean, he's a very, very long-term holder. He--he's as much of an activist's as other people.

SORKIN: Why would you--why would you say Warren Buffett would be an activist in that way?

MNUCHIN: In the sense of he's focused on long-term values and a long-term creation. He's--he's a long-term holder.

SORKIN: But the view is that activist come in, make some trouble--

MNUCHIN: And that your view. You're--you're categorizing how you referred to an activist.

SORKIN: So, how do you refer to an activist?

MNUCHIN: You're--you're using it in what I consider to be more of a derogatory term, as opposed to an activist could be an active investor. Obviously, private equity is definitely an active investor, so I mean private equity buys companies because they think they can run them better.

SORKIN: Okay. I'm going to pivot the conversation. We actually, as you saw, had a big debate about taxes, just now.

MNUCHIN: Know, I actually found that quite interesting.

SORKIN: And it--and it was fascinating, but I--I do want to ask you about where we are--in this idea--one of the questions that was raised that I think you may have missed--was this idea that we need more revenue. Broadly speaking, we need more revenue. If you look at the deficit, as you very well know, it looks like it's now going to get to over $1 trillion for--for 2020, for the first time. And so, the question that I would ask you, especially given that there's even conversations about a tax cut and I want to understand what tax--what the 2.0 cut may look like. How do you raise more revenue right now?

MNUCHIN: Well, the--the--the way--the number one way you raise more revenue is through growth. So, I--I think when--when we look at you know debt and sustainability, we look at debt relative to J--GDP. I think that when the president came into office, the number one economic issue he was focused on was growing the economy, and for a long time we had very low growth. There were people who said we could never grow at high numbers again. We had wages that hadn't grown and--and we came with an economic plan and said look, you can't cut your weight of prosperity you have to grow your way and again, we've grown revenues. Now, I just want to comment on one thing.

SORKIN: Okay.

MNUCHIN: Because people--you know when I've talked about the tax cuts paying for themselves or you look at the deficit and things like that, one of the things we did in the tax bill was we allowed for automatic expensing. So, obviously, that is the frontloading of investment and a back and in terms of revenues. We--we've actually grown tax receipts 3 percent, despite the fact that we allowed for a lot of expensing. So part of this is when you look at the deficit, you can't just look at it a moment in time, you look--you have to look at what are we going to do over a five or 10 year period to fix these issues?

SORKIN: Right. But you think it's--you think it's unfair to say that when--when--when you said initially when--when--when they're campaigning on--for the tax plan that it would pay for itself.

MNUCHIN: I still think it will, absolutely. The difference is 35 basis points of growth.

SORKIN: No, no, no. In terms of your expectations of where we would be today?

MNUCHIN: Absolutely. We're ahead of where we thought we would be today. I--I never said I thought it would pay for itself in year one. What I said is over a 10-year window, which is the way we analyze taxes it will pay for itself. And again, this is just math. If over this 10-year window we grow an extra 35 basis points a year it will pay for itself.

SORKIN: This is a longer conversation, and I know there's some--some--some tax experts in the room. I'll--I'll let them ask more on this, but I have a couple of quick other questions and then--and then we'll open it up. One, 50-year bond. Is it worth doing?

MNUCHIN: Yes. I think so. I mean you know and--and I talked about this. So again, this is something we looked at starting two years ago. I think it's--it's part of what we're looking at is we do have obviously a lot of debt at low-interest rates de-risking the government's position, so we're looking at potentially extending the portfolio and as part of that, one of the tools we'll look at, if there is proper demand we will issue fifty-year bonds.

SORKIN: A why not 100 years?

MNUCHIN: Well, we're going to start with 50 years and--and if the answer is 50 years are successful, we'll consider 100-year bonds.

SORKIN: Right. How worried are you about interest rates right now in this country and--and specifically what's happening in Europe and what it may ultimately mean here and then--then there for the power of the dollar and everything else?

MNUCHIN: Well, I think as you know in--in my role as Treasury Secretary--

SORKIN: I know.

MNUCHIN: I'm not going to specifically comment on interest rates in the United States, but I will comment on interest rates in Europe. I think that low-interest rates are good for economic growth. I think negative interest rates, unclear whether they're good for economic growth. I think that negative interest rates are bad for banking business. It's hard to grow an economy without having a healthy banking business. It'd be interesting to see what happens in Europe. I--I don't know why--I mean, I think the other thing we're going to see is with the spread between were 10-year treasuries and 10-year German bonds. My expectations are you're going to see a big flow of funds.

SORKIN: Right. Maybe two or three others really quick and then we will open it up, I promise. First, we were talking about the business Roundtable and their proposal that--that came out two weeks ago, where it effectively--there's now a conversation about--about purpose over profits if you will. You're-- you're a former investor, what do you think of--of what's happening in corporate America today? A, is it real, and is it good?

MNUCHIN: I--I think it's--I think it's a complicated issue and I think a little bit like we were--they were--I heard talking about taxes. You know, when the VAT tax started in Europe, also it started as a very little tax, and people said oh, it's not going to really have much impact.

SORKIN: Right.

MNUCHIN: And every year they kept raising the VAT tax. I think the--the problem with this conversation is profits are what create and investments or what create jobs to be reinvested. And if you go down this road and say oh, we no longer care about profits. We only care about purpose. You're--you're not going to have a very vibrant business community . Now, that's different than saying I do think companies should be long-term oriented.

I don't think companies need to necessarily focus on quarterly profits and hitting street earnings numbers, but I think ultimately a business's job is to deploy the capital correctly and to make profits.

SORKIN: So, there was I think five holdouts that were members of the Business Roundtable. Stephen Swordsman (PH) from--from Blackstone was one of them. If you were a member of the Business Roundtable, do you think you would've signed it?

MNUCHIN: I wouldn't have.

SORKIN: You wouldn't have signed it?

MNUCHIN: No.

SORKIN: That's fascinating. And--and its--it's fundamentally because you disagree with the premise.

MNUCHIN: Again, I think it's not a--I wouldn't have signed it because I think it's not a simple answer. So, in--in other words, people on a lot of these issues want a one-sentence or two-sentence answer. So again, I don't think it's--obviously businesses should have a purpose. To be profitable, you have to have a purpose. I think it's not as simple as saying we either have a purpose or we have profits. I think the problem with creating these one--a simple answer is it--it--it doesn't fully explore the issues. So, I personally think companies need to both have a purpose and have profits.

SORKIN: Okay. Let me ask you a different question then, I don't know if you saw the news today and I've been writing about this a lot in the paper recently, 145 CEOs in America wrote a letter to senators saying pass the bill on gun violence, both--

MNUCHIN: Again, I will say I--I--again, I have a lot of expertise, gun laws are--are not my area of expertise.

SORKIN: But let me ask you this, though. You saw Walmart--just a couple weeks ago decide that they were no longer going to stock certain--certain types of products, ammunition and other things like that. Do you--there's a view--there's a view on one side that this is what business should be doing. They should be using their role to do what they think is good for their business and others who think that this is like part of a culture war and business should not be part of this conversation. And so, I'm sort of curious where--where you land on that, irrespective of the issue itself.

MNUCHIN: I think you're talking about two different things. So, one is you're talking about businesses writing to Congress about certain positions, which again, I think in general, people have the right to have their opinions. I think this is a complicated issue that Congress is looking at.

SORKIN: Right.

MNUCHIN: So again, I think it's--it's--it's up--again, it's--it's an issue that's a complicated issue that business is looking at.

SORKIN: But I'm going to throw one other piece at it--at you and it's just interesting to me because Citigroup, Bank of America, and some others last year, decided that they were not going to actually--they were trying to distance themselves effectively from gun manufacturers, and when they did that, they got a lot of atta (PH) boy's from some customers, and there were other customers who were upset but interesting this is where the political part of it becomes so--so unique. There were lawmakers in certain states that were even a member of the SCC who effectively went after some of these companies.

MNUCHIN: Well, again, you're talking--again, I'm just saying these are--these are complicated issues, but you're talking about banks that are regulated and have FDIC insurance.

SORKIN: Right.

MNUCHIN: Which is a benefit and again, I think as it relates to any discrimination of laws, it's not the role of banks to discriminate against any laws, so I think part of the push back specifically on banks again is part of a broader view, which is of all the sudden banks start picking we like these laws, we don't like those laws, you--you lead to discrimination. Slightly--slightly different issue. And again, banks have a different obligation because they take insurance from the government.

SORKIN: But you, by the way, work with banks right now in a--in a sort of post 9/11 world for money laundering purposes--

MNUCHIN: Absolutely.

SORKIN: Human trafficking. You know, you--I've--I've argued you could use the banking system to look for suspicious buying patterns related to guns and that would actually be a very helpful thing.

MNUCHIN: Well, we do--we do a lot of things without commenting what we do. Obviously, our role of working with the banks and combating all different types of terrorist activities is something that we take great pride in.

SORKIN: Okay. I want to open up. I have just one final, very quick question for you. You asked me a question about TV. So, I'll ask you a question about TV since you are a producer yourself as well and a much more successful one than I ever was. There's a whole new streaming war, that's coming as you know, between Apple with their plus service, and Disney plus service, and Amazon, and Netflix. Do you want to pick a winner?

MNUCHIN: You know I'm not allowed to pick a winner, but I will say--so I can't comment on that because that would be endorsing something, which I'm now better educated on, but I will say, look I think it's terrific there's this type of competition.

SORKIN: Okay. We are going to leave it there, but I know there's so many people and there's microphones around the room, so and--and the Treasury Secretary's been kind enough to stay with us for another five or 10 minutes. We have a question there, and then I'll go to David Singer (SP).

QUESTION: Thank you, Secretary. I'm Vicki Aurora (SP) with Georgetown, and I'm pleased to hear you say that companies should be long-term oriented and as someone who works on climate change. I'm wondering what your philosophy is about how the government should be long-term oriented on this existential threat?

MNUCHIN: Well obviously you have a few because you've made a conclusion at the end of your question, so I--I assume you have a view on this. Again, I would put climate change is also a very, very complicated issue where you know the science is not clear on the different issues on different things.

Now, again, I would say--let me just give you an example, okay? You know, I drove an electric car when I was able to drive, and I loved my electric car, and I liked the idea of driving an electric car. Ultimately these electric cars and these batteries and everything else are going to create a lot of environmental issues. So, I--I only use this as just as an example of again, not my area of expertise so I can't comment on it. But I can tell you I do think the president and this administration, very much cares about clean air, clean water.

I do think U.S. companies have been very focused on cutting emissions, and I think one of the great things is the U.S. has an abundance of energy. I mean, liquid natural gas is a very, very clean, tremendous abundance of LNG.

SORKIN: Let me ask you, just a follow-up question, which relates to the automobile industry. In terms of some of the rollbacks that the administration was--is proposing on--on some of the automotive--automotive rules. Some of the carmakers think that the administration has gone too far.

MNUCHIN: I was kind of--I was kind of surprised to hear that the carmakers again, felt that way but again, not--not my area of expertise.

SORKIN: Okay. It's a longer conversation. David Singer?

SINGER: Secretary, David singer. I'm the national security correspondent for the times. You've been very active in the Iran sanctions, and we have seen in recent days, the French issued a proposal for a $15 billion line of credit for Iran guaranteed by the oil. And we've seen the president seemingly open to thinking about a line of credit, so tell us with this undercut the sanctions as you are imagining them? Is it a relief on the maximum pressure campaign that you talk so much about?

MNUCHIN: Sure, so thank you. I think that's a good question. So, let me clarify some of these issues and--and let me first say, you know there's certain things I came into government. I knew a lot about there's certain things I didn't know anything about. Sanctions was one of the things and national security, a tremendous career staff at Treasury. You know I feel like I got a Ph.D. in my first 90 days and we're very proud of the fact that at treasury we've done more sanctions than have ever done--have ever been done before. And--and they are a very, very important national security tool. They absolutely work.

So first, let me just say as relates to Iran. The sanctions are working. There is no question that they're having an economic impact on Iran, and the only reason why they're contemplating changes, behavior, or conversation, or everything else is because of the economic issues. We have had--I've participated in direct discussions with President Trump and President Macron on these issues.

Secretary Pompeo and I work very actively together. The French understand clearly that they cannot give a line of credit without our consent that it would be a violation of the sanctions. So there is not a "proposal" from France right now to give the Iranians $15 billion. There are various different discussions going along the way.

I've seen some reporting recently, which is misinformation that I or other people want to loosen up on sanctions. Secretary Pompeo and I are executing the president's strategy of maximum pressure, and we think it's working. Simultaneously the president has said he's willing to sit down and have a conversation with no conditions. So that's--that's--that's our strategy.

SORKIN: Okay. Let's sneak in--

MNUCHIN: Did--did I answer your question clearly enough?

SORKIN: (OFF-MIC) I--I--I'm not sure whether we understand whether (INAUDIBLE) proposal in order to get those negotiations (INAUDIBLE).

MNUCHIN: Again, I'm not going to go into any confidential discussions, but let me just repeat, which is we are executing a maximum pressure campaign. That is what we're doing, and the French understand that they can't give a $15 billion line of credit without our consent.

SORKIN: Okay. Why don't we go rapid fire because I know there's lots of hands over here? And then we'll get over to John O'Brien, as well.

QUESTION: Mr. Secretary, David Damschen, Utah State Treasurer. Thank you so much for joining us. There's roughly $26 billion in federal savings bonds that are matured and no longer accruing interest. Senator Kennedy, as you may be aware, has dropped a bill that would allow information related to those monies be passed to state treasures. State treasures are very good at reuniting lost monies with the rightful owner. What are your feelings about Treasury assisting treasures in reuniting those lost monies with rightful owners, $26 billion? Thank you.

MNUCHIN: So, you know I--I just read this article's I was coming up. I think it was a political article on how I'm such a micromanager, which I take as a great compliment by the way, and my--looking at all the tax rags, but I can tell me being a micromanager I actually understand this issue extremely well. So part of the problem is a lot of these records are on very, very old microfiche--even if we have the records, so the problem we're trying to figure out is--I mean, first of all, we want to get the money back to the rightful holders.

We want to get them to the holders. How you go about doing that because the average amount of money that a person has is--is--is very--were talking about very, very small per person, although it's big in the aggregate. And a lot of time the cost of the government to figure out who actually has it is going to be more expensive than the person has. So I--I--I've had--I've had multiple meetings, I probably had a dozen meetings on this specific issue and us trying to figure out how we can work with the states, and I think we're starting a pilot program but I--I appreciate it, and we're working on it.

SORKIN: I think we have one more over here. By the way, real--the flipside of that, by the way, is the tax group wants to get more money. Obviously, just to get more money for--for the IRS. Would you--would you be in favor of the IRS having a much bigger budget?

MNUCHIN: I--I--I would. So, I mean, again, when I say a much bigger budget, we--we're advocating for more money for the IRS. One of the things we want more money for is--is technology modernization. I think as you know we have the largest database of personal information, particularly in this cybersecurity issue. I think that one, we need to make sure we protect it. And two, taxpayers deserve better online information. There's no reason why as a taxpayer people shouldn't have the same level of communication--

SORKIN: But is it more about that or more about enforcement?

MNUCHIN: Well, again, if we have better technology, we can use the technology for enforcement and--and a lot of information is matched today so, yes, we--we're advocating for more money for the IRS.

SORKIN: Okay. I know--I know the Treasurer may have to go on a moment-- going on.

MNUCHIN: I'll--I'll take a couple more questions and then we'll let you go.

SORKIN: Okay. John O'Brien?

QUESTION: Mr. Secretary, first of all--

MNUCHIN: Hey, John, and thank you for everything you're doing.

QUESTION: Thank you.

MNUCHIN: Terrific, thank you very much.

QUESTION: Thank you. Thanks for your efforts around the Freedman's Bank. Thank you for your efforts around the qualified opportunity zones, which I think potentially--which is still in front of us. And thank you and (INAUDIBLE) for the efforts around CRA reform, which would hopefully direct billions of dollars into undeserved, still working on all of that.

With regard to repairing the latter of aspiration that was referred to by Abigail and others earlier. What would you think philosophically about providing tax relief and/or tax break? However, you want to structure it to the wealthy individuals or corporations who facilitate massive internships and massive apprenticeships for those who are not in the room.

I keep saying that you hang around nine broke people you'll be the 10th so, we've got to get folks who are brilliant and amazing but are connected back in from the streets into the suites, and I think internships and apprenticeships does that. But I think there needs to be an incentive to do it philosophically. I know it's not exactly your lane, but you have incredible influence in this whole dialogue and this discussion. Philosophically, is this something that you think might work?

MNUCHIN: Well, first of all, let me just say again. I appreciate the work you've done in these areas. I think apprenticeships are very important. I also think, and this is an area you know we've worked with you on financial literacy is also very important. So, some of these issues and Ivanka Trump has done a great job spearheading this out of the White House with--with many companies. Job training, apprenticeship--incentivizing companies to do this and cutting back regulations so that companies can do it effectively. Anything we can do to increase this area and yes, philosophically if we have to look at tax benefits that's something that we'd consider.

SORKIN: Okay. (INAUDIBLE)

QUESTION: Speaker--Secretary, people say terrible things about you online, you and your wife. Your boss, you know, is known for being uncivil to a lot of people. In term--both in terms generally of what set on Twitter and specifically about this administration's relationship with the press, which I think you know is toxic on both sides. The president has said the press is the enemy. The people--the press pursues him for what is basically an in--innocent misstatement about Alabama and our hurricane. Is there any way to put the genie back in the bottle or are we stuck with what we have right now? And--and how does it feel to be someone who is targeted this way?

MNUCHIN: Well, I can only talk for myself. I think I have good relationships with plenty of people in the process. That's why I'm here.

SORKIN: I appreciate you being here.

MNUCHIN: As it relates to online, you know I think one of the problems, and--and again, I don't have the answer, but you--you can go online you know for almost any person or any issue, and 50 percent of the things are broadly nice, and 50 percent of things are nasty. And again, not my areas of expertise, but you know as it relates to some of these companies are, they publishers? Should there be some level of responsibility for it? I--I don't know the answer, but you--you're touching on a lot of complicated issues, and you know online has taken a very, very important role, and in many ways, it's very good.

I mean I--I do think the fact that the president and other people can communicate as broadly as they can through an online channel is actually, I think a good thing. I mean there was a time where the press, you know, filtered everything. That--that's no longer the case, but I think you--you raise some very important issues as it relates to issues online and other things.

SORKIN: Okay. On that note, we want to thank you.

MNUCHIN: Thank you.

SORKIN: For this conversation. I really appreciate you being here. Thank you very, very much.

MNUCHIN: Terrific.

(APPLAUSE)

SORKIN: Mr. Secretary, thank you so much.

(APPLAUSE)

MNUCHIN: Pleasure.

urn:contentItem:5WN1-4971-F03R-N4WR-00000-00Treasury Secretary Mnuchin: I won't be talking about bitcoin in ten years2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:12ZLexisNexisTreasury Secretary Mnuchin: I won't be talking about bitcoin in ten yearsJacob Wolinsky

Jul 24, 2019( ValueWalk: http://www.valuewalk.com/ Delivered by Newstex) CNBC Transcript: Treasury Secretary Mnuchin Speaks with CNBC[1]'s 'Squawk Box' Today   https://d2wsh2n0xua73e.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/teven-Mnuchin.jpg WHEN: Today, Wednesday, July 24, 2019 WHERE: CNBC's 'Squawk Box[2]' The following is the unofficial transcript of a CNBC interview with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on CNBC's 'Squawk Box' (M-F 6AM - 9AM) today, Wednesday, July 24th. The following is a link to video of the interview on CNBC.com: Get The Full Ray Dalio Series in PDF Get the entire 10-part series on Ray Dalio in PDF. Save it to your desktop, read it on your tablet, or email to your colleagues Q2 hedge fund letters, conference, scoops etc[3] Watch Treasury Secretary Mnuchin's full interview on trade, Big Tech and more   https://player.cnbc.com/p/gZWlPC/cnbc_global?playertype=synd...uid;=7000090543...e;=640_360[4] ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: Let's get to the Treasury Secretary.

The interview of the morning. Sources telling CNBC that American trade negotiations[5] will be heading to China either late this week or sometime next week for face-to-face talks—though a final trade deal could still be months away. Joining us right now is U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and we're thrilled to have him here. Good morning to you. We want to get your take. Right now,- just we want to start off on sort of with what is going to happen in this next week and exactly what you think the timeline looks like. STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, good morning. It's great to be here with you. The timeline on the budget or the timeline on China? ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: I want to go to China first, given that markets this morning, both in China and the U.S. seem to be moving on this expectation that there's going to be a team, including Lighthizer and potentially yourself, headed there. STEVEN MNUCHIN: Right. So, Ambassador Lighthizer and I will depart on Monday. We will spend Tuesday and Wednesday in Shanghai. The reason why we're going to Shanghai is that the host country, China[6], has invited us there. There's a significance to them of the Shanghai communique and the symbolism, obviously, of that important agreement. So, hopefully I'll take that as good news that we'll be making progress next week. But I would say there's a lot of issues. So, my expectation is that this will be followed up with a meeting back in D.C. after this. And hopefully we will continue to progress. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: Mr. Secretary, can you explain sort of where the White House is with Huawei at this point? Because that seems to be such a pivotal chess piece in these conversations. There are U.S. companies that clearly want to do business with Huawei. Huawei yesterday just announced that they're laying off 600 people in the United States and I wanted to get your thoughts on that. STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, I think, as you know, the President hosted a group of tech CEOs in the Oval Office. He also had Secretary Ross, myself, Ambassador Lighthizer, Director Kudlow[7]. We had a very good discussion. Part of the discussion was obviously on Huawei. Part of the discussion, actually, was on other important technology issues and immigration issues. But the Huawei issue is being driven out of Commerce. And what Commerce has said is that they will issue waivers for items that don't impact national security. So, where there are commodity products or issues that don't impact national security, Commerce will be proceeding with that. And I think it was a very productive two-way discussion for the President. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: Related to that, and I think this has to do with national security, but also, corporations being patriotic. You probably saw the comments late last week from Peter Thiel saying that he thought that Google, that Alphabet was treasonous. And then President Trump said that he was going to look into those comments. There was a -- there's some people in - both Chinese officials and Chinese executives who, at least have said to me, how is that any different than what Huawei is relative to the U.S. -- to the Chinese government in terms of that relationship? STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, let me just say the President did look into that. as well as I. The CEO of Google is with us this week. We both had very direct discussions. They assured us that there is very, very limited work. The only work that they're doing is some minimal open source work. They continue to do work with us in certain areas of DOD. And I think, you, Google is an American company that wants to help out the U.S. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: So, Peter Thiel's comments were misguided? STEVEN MNUCHIN: I don't see any area -- again, the President and I did diligence on this issue and we're not aware of any areas where Google working with the Chinese government in a way that in any way raises concerns. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: Okay. Let's pivot real quick to the debt ceiling[8] and the debt deal. I want to read you a comment, this is from FreedomWorks, about this deal that has all been struck. It says, 'Washington has all but abandoned economic sanity. With this deal GOP leadership has ceded the ground on fiscal responsibility for which years -- which for years was supposed to be the core tenet of the party.' What do you make of that critique? STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, first thing I'd say is that spending is an issue that has to be a bipartisan agreement. So, this can't be an issue of just what the President wants to do, what the Republicans want to do or what the Democrats wanted to do. It wasn't just because of the debt ceiling. I mean, we're very happy that we got a 2 1/2 year extension to the debt ceiling, including our special powers. But any spending required bipartisan agreement. So, the first issue is that the President was very determined to fund the military and make sure that we funded veterans. So, we held expenses to a modest 2% increase a year, which is in line with inflation. So, I think we were very careful on the spending issues. We think we'll grow revenues in excess of 4% over this period of time a year. And, you know, this had to be a bipartisan agreement. So, people who said we should have increased military and decreased nonmilitary, you know, one, we had to take care of our vets and two, we needed bipartisan support. That's a cost of losing the house. BECKY QUICK: Mr. Secretary, can we go back to what you were talking about with Google and both you and the President kind of looking into those claims? We had Ash Carter on the show last week, the former Defense Secretary. And he had said, when we asked about those same questions about whether Google was cooperating with the Chinese government in ways that could be considered treasonous, he kind of demurred from that but then focused on the idea that he's been disappointed with some of the companies in the Silicon Valley[9], the idea they have not wanted to do work for defense department, the idea that they've kind of caved to some of their employees with those feelings. He seems to be of the belief that if you're an American company you have benefited from the government and what this country has done for you and you should be willing to do work for the government in turn. Do you share those thoughts? STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, I do share those thoughts. But, you know, I would also balance that -- I want to be careful because a lot of companies cooperate with the Defense Department. Some of our most important critical technology companies. And, as I just mentioned, in my conversations with Google and we researched this, there are areas. They're cooperating. Having said that, private businesses do have the right to make decisions. They're owned by shareholders, they have boards that control them. But I do think it's important and I would say almost all the technology -- leading technology companies in the U.S. do cooperate with the government in very significant ways. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: Mr. Secretary, related to technology, the Department of Justice said yesterday that they're going to look into some of the big tech companies that were at the White House yesterday, in fact, and consider the anti-trust issues that are involved. What's your take right now? Do you believe that these big companies, and I'm thinking of the Facebooks and the Googles and the Apples and the Amazons of the world, do you believe that they are -- that they're hurting competition? STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, let me just say I think it's good that the Attorney General[10] is going to look into this. I think it's an important issue and I look forward to him reporting back to the President and hearing his recommendations. I think, as you know, if you look at Amazon, although, you know, there are certain benefits to it, they have destroyed the retail industry across the United States. So, there's no question they have limited competition. There's areas where they have really hurt small businesses. So, I don't think this is a one size fits all. And I don't - you know, I don't have an opinion going in, other than I think it's absolutely right that the Attorney General is looking into these issues and I look forward to listening to his recommendations to the President. BECKY QUICK: Is Amazon's competition any different than what Walmart used to be a decade ago? STEVEN MNUCHIN: It is different. In a way, it's the same and in a way, it's different. I mean, people had the concerns about Walmart. I think, as you see, Walmart developed a business where small businesses could continue to keep -- compete with them. And look, Walmart ceded a lot of the retail business to Amazon. So, these are important issues I look forward to hearing from the Attorney General. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: How do you weigh the size and scale issue of some of the big U.S. companies versus when you think about how we compete internationally? One of the things that you hear out of Silicon Valley from the Silicon Valley executives is, they say, 'Look we're trying to compete aggressively with China, which you're going to negotiate as well on trade. And if we become smaller or hemmed in and have to limit ourselves, it's actually going to become harder to compete.' STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, I think that's a very important statement. And that's why I think there's not a one size that fits all approach. So, people talk about the FAANG stocks like they're all the same. Each company is very different. Apple competes head-to-head with Huawei[11], with Samsung, with other companies. So, I think there's no question, the size and scale of Apple is very important. They also have an ecosystem. So, you know, I don't think you can talk about competition amongst all of these companies in the same way. JOE KERNEN: Mr. Treasury Secretary, the President has overtly actually talked about a weaker dollar being in our best interests and in terms of -- on moves by Jay Powell and the Fed. And how he feels we're not on a level playing field with the rest of the world in terms of the Central Banks and accommodation. In the past, we have never had a Treasury Secretary do anything other than say we have a strong dollar policy and we advocate a strong dollar policy. So, you could be the first one in history to say we have a weak dollar policy. Is that in your view something that would benefit the United States if we could weaken the dollar for exports? STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, let me just comment that although Treasury Secretaries have always said that they believe in the strong dollar, Treasury Secretaries have also been particularly careful about commenting on the dollar. And, you know, I remember last year- JOE KERNEN: We did that to you in Davos. I know. I thought you forgot. STEVEN MNUCHIN: Davos -- my limited comments got misinterpreted, okay, all over the place. So, let me just clarify this. I think the dollar is the reserve currency of the world. It's in our interest, we want to maintain it. A stable dollar is very important. And over the long-term period of time, again, the long term, I do believe in a strong dollar which signifies a strong U.S. economy, a strong stock market and particularly because of the President's economic policies. We have growth in the U.S. that has outpaced everywhere else. We have a ton of money, as a result of tax cuts, regulatory relief coming in to the U.S. So, just as the stock market has gone up as a result of these policies, there's also -- these markets are the largest traded markets in the world. So, you know what I would say is that the dollar trades as much as anything in the world every day and there's buyers and sellers. And right now, there's a lot of people who want to invest in the U.S. and that creates a lot of demand for dollars. JOE KERNEN: Wow. That's a really nuanced answer that you give. So, you don't advocate a weak dollar policy near term, per se? STEVEN MNUCHIN: I am not going to advocate a weak dollar policy near term as the Treasury Secretary. JOE KERNEN: Although the President seems to be in some respects. STEVEN MNUCHIN: I think the President is very focused on a lot of issues. He is focused on our trade issues. He is focused on our economic issues. I think you know where he is on the Federal Reserve[12]. I don't need to make any comments on that. JOE KERNEN: Right. STEVEN MNUCHIN: But the President is very pleased with the economic performance. And, you know, the next election is really going to be an election about two different views. You know, our view is about growth, growing revenues, faster than expenses. Having free markets. Making sure the U.S. economy grows creating job opportunities. And the other view is very different. So, if you have concerns about, you know, our budget deal, you can imagine what a Democrat-controlled White House would look like. JOE KERNEN: Right. Well, it's hard to tell the difference, though. STEVEN MNUCHIN: --in terms of tax and spend. That's not fair at all-- JOE KERNEN: Some people - some people think it is. Well -- STEVEN MNUCHIN: We cut taxes - JOE KERNEN: -- definitely celebrating the deal that was -- in the second -- if there is a second term, we have heard rumor that maybe spending cuts are going to be something that the administration would focus on. Are you still going to be here for the next - STEVEN MNUCHIN: I'm definitely going to be here with the President for the second term and the President is determined on a bipartisan basis, we look at expense controls. So, whether it's something like Reagan did, you know, we're going to look at -- again we want to look at how we spend money on the military but we want to do it efficiently. So, we'll want to look at how we spend in the military. And, you know, as I said, our job is cut taxes, grow revenues faster than expenses, grow the economy. And that's what the President is doing. BECKY QUICK: Secretary Mnuchin, I know it's difficult, we keep asking you to explain the President's thought process with some of these things. Maybe you can, maybe you can't on this issue. But, if he's convinced this is a great economy, why does he also want the Fed to cut rates? STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, again, I want to be careful because these are the President's views. Because you know as Treasury Secretary I'm not going to comment on interest rates. BECKY QUICK:Right. STEVEN MNUCHIN: But the President believes that we have very low inflation. So I think when the fed - I think he believes when the Fed raised rates, they had much higher inflation expectations. And because we have had very low inflation that we should cut rates so they're more in line with the rest of the world. And, you know, again, when you look at interest rates in the United States, everybody will agree, you have to look at real interest rates. So, you know, the Fed has models. We have models. Sometimes these models turn out to be right. Sometimes they turn out to be wrong. And, again, without me commenting on what the fed is going to do, obviously, the market expects the Fed to cut. So, I -- if they do that, I think you'll see a continued improvement in the economy throughout the year. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: Mr. Secretary, two other quick questions. Boeing announced their earnings this morning. There are still questions about when that 737 Max plane is going to get into the air. How concerned are you about the international reaction to Boeing[13] right now? STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, Boeing is a great American company. And they obviously -- they have a big Defense Department business. They have a big commercial business. There's no question—this is very important to us. We compete, Boeing versus Airbus, every day. I think, as you know, the President has said he's concerned about the 737 Max. Quite frankly he thinks they should bring back the 757 and look at selling 757s. We want to absolutely make sure that before the 737 Max flies that it's safe. But I think there's no question, Boeing has the financial capacity to fix this. But I think we need to make sure they're fixed and we need to figure out how they continue to compete against Airbus. Because they are a leading U.S. company. JOE KERNEN: Secretary, would the fiscal restraint in the second term include entitlements? Which the President never talks about, I don't think, in terms of the unfunded liabilities which some people think -- I don't know, I hear $80 trillion, $100 trillion. Something eventually -- it's not a great subject to talk about in an election, I understand that. Medicare, things like that. But would that ever be on the President's plate, or would you put it there? Do you worry about entitlement -- not being able to deliver on all these promises? STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, I have not spoken to the President about this issue. We're really focused on the economic issues today. So, this is just my own personal thoughts and in no way, do I want to attribute them to the President. JOE KERNEN: You keep saying that a lot. STEVEN MNUCHIN: I think we need to make sure that we guarantee people who we had promises that we keep those promises. So, that's very important. But we have a $4 trillion expenses— discretionary is just part of it. There are many things in the nondiscretionary part of the budgets that we can look at without, in any way breaking promises to the people who rely on these: our seniors, veterans and other areas. And, again, this will need to be looked at on a bipartisan basis. You know, hopefully we'll take back the house but even with the house you need bipartisan support in the Senate to get these things done with 60 votes. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: And Mr. Secretary, we could not leave this interview without asking you at least a question about crypto. The last time we had you on, I think Joe tried to convince you about the merits of bitcoin. You talked about regulating or the need to regulate Libra. And the question I ultimately sort of land with is do you think that all cryptocurrencies will ultimately have to be regulated like -- I don't know, like a commodity or like a currency? Meaning that especially digital currencies like a bitcoin that don't actually have a central organizer will have to have the same kind of regulations and how that would happen? STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, all cryptocurrencies today in the United States are subject to regulation. They're subject to the Bank Secrecy Act, they're subject to our Money Laundering and they're subject to the same issues that physical. So, whether you're Moneygram or whether you're Western Union or whether you're trading bitcoin, you are subject to that. And I can tell you there was 100% agreement from the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors, those rules we will enforce throughout the world. So, we will make sure that cryptocurrencies are not used for bad activities. I think, as I have said in the past, I am concerned that bitcoin is used for a lot of illicit activities[14]. We have a working group to combat that. And I'm concerned that consumers don't understand the speculative issue of these things. And as it relates to Libra, we have made very clear to Facebook that before they start this, this needs to be something that passes our regulations. And again, there was 100% support at the G7 on these issues. So, we support -- we like payment systems that reduce costs. But we don't support unregulated bad actors using anything - any type of currency or cryptocurrency. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: When you talk about the working group looking at bitcoin, what specifically are you looking at and what do you think the options are in terms of what you can do? STEVEN MNUCHIN: Well, we're looking at all of the crypto assets. So, I mean, we talk about bitcoin just because it's the largest. But it has to be a level playing field. And this is a working group that includes all the regulators: the Fed, the OCC, the Consumer Protection Bureau, The S.E.C., the CFTC. So, we'll look at it, whether you're trading a derivative, whether you're trading cash, whether you're looking at it in a payment system. We're going to make sure we have a unified approach. And my guess is that there are going to be more regulations that come out from all of these agencies to make sure that we keep the U.S. financial system safe. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: You think we'll be talk about bitcoin in ten years from now? STEVEN MNUCHIN: I won't be talking about bitcoin in ten years. I can assure you that. JOE KERNEN: But you might be in at least six years as the Treasury Secretary[15], as you just said. STEVEN MNUCHIN: Exactly. I would bet even in five or six years I'm no longer talking about bitcoin as Treasury Secretary. I'll have other priorities. JOE KERNEN: You'll be loaded up on bitcoin. And a gazillionaire. STEVEN MNUCHIN: I can assure you, I will personally not be loaded up on bitcoin. JOE KERNEN: Never say never. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: It sounds like the Secretary is not convinced about bitcoin. Mr. Secretary, we appreciate you taking the time to speak with us this morning. We hope to see you very soon. STEVEN MNUCHIN: Thank you. ANDREW ROSS SORKIN: Thank you. The post Treasury Secretary Mnuchin: I won't be talking about bitcoin in ten years[16] appeared first on ValueWalk[17]. value.Title: Treat big tech firms as publishers

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YSD-4FF1-JDKC-R1CR-00000-00Treat big tech firms as publishers2020-04-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:11ZLexisNexisTreat big tech firms as publishersNew Delhi

New Delhi, April 28 -- Are leading Internet firms such as Facebook, Twitter and Google, as operators of social media platforms, publishers of editorialised content (much like the Hindustan Times is), or are they indiscriminate platforms that offer open access to anything that you might wish to see?

The debate sounds nerdy at first - a sort of philosophical enquiry that should only concern professors and legal scholars as a matter of business regulation. But this seemingly narrow intellectual question is increasingly becoming a central matter of urgent concern in the context of Indian democracy - and, indeed, democracy and the free flow of information around the world. Foreign governments are moving to impose new responsibilities on dominant tech firms. Australia, for instance, is forcing Facebook and Google to pay news companies for displaying their stories; French antitrust officials have ordered Google to negotiate with local media firms to pay for displaying their content; and in the United States, a fierce political war rages on between liberals and conservatives on this very issue.

Let's go back to that philosophical question for a moment, though. Publishers have always held a vaunted position in society. Traditional media formats - daily newspapers, broadcast television networks and radio stations - once consumed the public's attention. My grandfather would comb through newspapers and news magazines every day, while my grandmother listened to the radio all day, every day - not uncommon for those of their generation. The result was that we came to know not only the voices and faces that graced these outlets, but the publishing houses and media personalities behind the businesses. This intense aura about the media ecosystem - a world that could make someone famous - gave news organisations great power. They had the power to convey the news - and with that power, came great responsibility.

As with any line of business, news organisations cannot be expected to necessarily and voluntarily demonstrate that responsibility - by, for instance, not spreading political falsehoods, hateful messaging, and other vitriol. To put it differently: Absent meaningful regulation, businesses operating in a free market economy, including media outlets, will do whatever they wish to maximise shareholder returns. Profit displaces social considerations.

So to ensure they would act responsibly, the government created a policy framework.

In India, the contours of media regulation have become sophisticatedly diverse, with laws such as the Press Council Act, 1978, the Drugs and Magic Remedies (Objectionable Advertisements) Act, 1954, the Newspaper (Price and Page) Act, 1956, and the Cinematograph Act, 1952.

To quote from an example, the last of these - a reform of the Indian film industry enacted 70 years ago - notes that a "film shall not be certified for public exhibition if, in the opinion of the authority competent to grant the certificate, the film or any part of it is against the interests of 1 (the sovereignty and integrity of India) the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or involves defamation or contempt of court or is likely to incite the commission of any offence." Without the law, the government couldn't be sure that an intrepid director might just slip offending content into mass-market films every now and then.

Some might argue that Facebook and Google should be treated like publishers, too; they now dominate the media sector in India and often facilitate the dissemination of offending content. They have, until now, been regarded as open platforms, which allow any and all speech (different kinds of views/all shades of opinion)but can remove whatever they wish - a conceptualisation originally stemming from Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, a 1996 US law that simultaneously affirms that Internet companies won't "be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information" and won't "be held liable on account of any action voluntarily taken in good faith to restrict access to or availability of material". The idea was simple: Let the Internet grow and develop its own commercial standards as necessary.

Here is the problem. This benevolent regulatory framework has enabled Facebook to claim it acts as a publisher and reap the censorship rights thereof, but turn around and also claim it is an undiscerning platform to reap the benefits of free speech leniency. A more just regime might, instead of giving the firm a free pass on both ends, hold its feet to the fire on both counts. There can be no doubt the company acts as some novel form of entity in between; even the company's lawyers have suggested that the company possesses a "quintessential publisher function" over the "protected" practice of determining "what to publish and the decision of what not to publish" - while Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has also contended the company "should err on the side of greater expression."

So, if it is true that Internet firms have editorial power - and it is, so long as they decide what specific news stories, search results, and social media posts to show us among the billions of possibilities - then let us treat them as such. The responsibility must now lie with the national government to do right by its citizens- many of whom have been targeted, misled, and pilloried, which has been enabled by Internet platforms. The time has come for the imposition of decency in exchange for continued participation in the Indian consumer market.

Dipayan Ghosh is co-director of the Digital Platforms & Democracy Project at the Harvard Kennedy School

The views expressed are personal

urn:contentItem:5YS9-DSH1-JDKC-R24V-00000-00Treat big tech firms as publishers2020-04-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:11ZLexisNexisTreat big tech firms as publishersIndia

India, April 28 -- Are leading Internet firms such as Facebook, Twitter and Google, while offering several services, also publishers of editorialised content (much like the Hindustan Times is), or are they indiscriminate platforms that offer open access to any sort of content that you might wish to see?

The debate sounds nerdy at first - a sort of philosophical enquiry that should only concern professors and legal scholars as a matter of business regulation. But this seemingly narrow intellectual question is increasingly becoming a central matter of great concern in the context of Indian democracy - and, indeed, democracy and the free flow of information around the world. Foreign governments are moving to impose new responsibilities on dominant tech firms. Australia, for instance, is forcing Facebook and Google to pay news companies for their content; French antitrust officials have ordered Google to negotiate with local media firms to pay for displaying their content; and in the United States, a fierce political war rages on between liberals and conservatives on this issue.

Let's go back to that philosophical question for a moment, though. Publishers have always held a vaunted position in society. Traditional media formats - daily newspapers, broadcast television networks and radio stations - once consumed the public's attention. My grandfather would comb through newspapers and news magazines every day, while my grandmother listened to the radio all day, every day - not uncommon for those of their generation. The result was that we came to know not only the voices and faces that graced these outlets, but the publishing houses and media personalities behind the businesses. This intense aura about the media ecosystem - a world that could make someone famous - gave news organisations great power. They had the power to convey the news, and with that power, came great responsibility.

As with any line of business, news organisations cannot be expected to necessarily and voluntarily exhibit that responsibility - by, for instance, not spreading political falsehoods, hateful messaging, and other vitriol. To put it differently: Absent meaningful regulation, businesses operating in a free market economy, including media outlets, will do whatever they wish to maximise shareholder returns. Profit comes before any other consideration.

But to ensure they were responsible, a policy framework was created.

In India, the contours of media regulation have become sophisticatedly diverse, with laws such as the Press Council Act, 1978, the Drugs and Magic Remedies (Objectionable Advertisements) Act, 1954, the Newspaper (Price and Page) Act, 1956, and the Cinematograph Act, 1952.

To quote from an example, the last of these - a reform of the Indian film industry enacted in 1952 - notes that a "film shall not be certified for public exhibition if, in the opinion of the authority competent to grant the certificate, the film or any part of it is against the interests of 1 (the sovereignty and integrity of India) the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or involves defamation or contempt of court or is likely to incite the commission of any offence." Without the law, the government couldn't be sure that an intrepid director might just slip offending content into mass-market films every now and then.

Some might argue that Facebook and Google should be treated like publishers, too; they now dominate the media sector in India and often facilitate the dissemination of offending content. They have, until now, been regarded as open platforms, which allow any and all speech (different kinds of views/all shades of opinion) but can remove whatever they wish - a conceptualisation originally stemming from Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, a 1996 US law that simultaneously affirms that Internet companies won't "be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information" and won't "be held liable on account of any action voluntarily taken in good faith to restrict access to or availability of material". The idea was simple: Let the Internet grow and develop its own commercial standards as necessary.

Here is the problem. This benevolent regulatory framework has enabled Facebook to claim it acts as a publisher and reap the censorship rights thereof, but turn around and also claim it is an undiscerning platform to reap the benefits of free speech leniency. A more just regime might, instead of giving the firm a free pass on both ends, hold its feet to the fire on both counts. There can be no doubt that it is somewhere in between; even the company's lawyers have suggested that the company possesses a "quintessential publisher function" over the "protected" practice of determining "what to publish and the decision of what not to publish".

So, if it is true that Internet firms have editorial power - and it is, so long as they decide what specific news stories, search results, and social media posts to show us among the billions of possibilities - then let us treat them as such. The responsibility must now lie with the national government to do right by its citizens - many of whom have been targeted, misled, and pilloried, enabled by Internet platforms. The time has come for the imposition of decency in exchange for continued participation in the Indian consumer market.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VP2-B1S1-DYX1-H2DR-00000-00Treating consumers as products2019-03-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:11ZLexisNexisEditorialPg. A20Treating consumers as productsLetters to the Editor

The March 16 Economy & Business article "Attorneys general focus on targeting tech giants" was a reminder that, in the age of political partisanship gone berserk, congressional and regulatory gridlock and dysfunction can be overcome only by state attorneys general determined to investigate, at the local level, matters of national importance that have escaped scrutiny in Washington.

Whether you believe that "Big Tech" companies such as Google and Facebook provide valuable services for users or abuse their power over users' personal data for pecuniary gain, there is no denying that these behemoths treat users as their products and market us in ways most users know virtually nothing about, at least until some outrageous business practice comes to light in the media.

A good starting point for the attorneys general would be a requirement that any tech company that collects, disseminates or markets consumers' data obtain affirmative opt-in consent from users after posting their terms of use and privacy policies in plain English. At present, these online documents are written in a form of bafflegab impenetrable to anyone lacking a degree in law or information science, or both.

Steven Sarfatti, Cabin John

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VP2-G1F1-DXXY-30CR-00000-00Treating consumers as products2019-03-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:12ZLexisNexisEDITORIAL COPYPg. A20Every ZoneTreating consumers as productsLetters to the Editor

The March 16 Economy & Business article "Attorneys general focus on targeting tech giants" was a reminder that, in the age of political partisanship gone berserk, congressional and regulatory gridlock and dysfunction can be overcome only by state attorneys general determined to investigate, at the local level, matters of national importance that have escaped scrutiny in Washington.

Whether you believe that "Big Tech" companies such as Google and Facebook provide valuable services for users or abuse their power over users' personal data for pecuniary gain, there is no denying that these behemoths treat users as their products and market us in ways most users know virtually nothing about, at least until some outrageous business practice comes to light in the media.

A good starting point for the attorneys general would be a requirement that any tech company that collects, disseminates or markets consumers' data obtain affirmative opt-in consent from users after posting their terms of use and privacy policies in plain English. At present, these online documents are written in a form of bafflegab impenetrable to anyone lacking a degree in law or information science, or both.

Steven Sarfatti , Cabin John
